docs.title: Getting Started with Bash
docs.text:
Before we dive into writing code, let's make sure you have access to a Bash shell. Most Unix-like operating systems (such as Linux and macOS) come with Bash pre-installed. You can also use terminal emulators like Git Bash on Windows to run Bash commands.

Once you have access to a Bash shell, open your terminal or command prompt, and let's start scripting!

docs.title: Writing Your First "Hello, World!" Program
docs.text:
In Bash, writing a "Hello, World!" program is incredibly simple. Open your text editor or terminal and type the following command:

echo "Hello, World!"

That's it! This single line of code is all you need to print "Hello, World!" to the console.

docs.title: Understanding the Code
docs.text:
Let's break down what's happening in this one-liner:

echo: This command is used to print text to the console.

"Hello, World!": This is the text we want to print. Make sure to enclose it in double quotes to preserve spaces and special characters.

docs.title: Running Your Script
docs.text:
Now that you've written your Bash script, let's run it:

  • Save your script with a .sh extension, for example, hello_world.sh.

  • Open your terminal or command prompt.

  • Navigate to the directory where your script is saved using the cd command.

  • Type the following command to make your script executable:

chmod +x hello_world.sh
* Finally, run your script using the following command:

./hello_world.sh

You should see "Hello, World!" printed to the console.

Congratulations! You've successfully written and executed your first "Hello, World!" program in Bash. This is just the beginning of your journey into Bash scripting.

As you continue to explore Bash, you'll discover its vast capabilities for automating tasks, writing complex scripts, and managing system configurations. Whether you're a system administrator, a developer, or just someone interested in learning a new skill, Bash scripting is a valuable tool to have in your toolkit.
